#Text=2. Literature Review
#Text=2.1. Ride-hailing as an Emerging Mode of Transportation
#Text=Ride-hailing is a transportation service that allows passengers to request a ride in a real-time via smartphone applications that link passengers to nearby drivers .
#Text=Once a driver accepts the request , the passenger can evaluate the waiting time and decide whether to accept the ride .
#Text=Both the passenger and the driver can use Global Position System ( GPS ) navigation during the trip , and the application guides the driver to shortcuts and less-congested roadways .
#Text=Many terms are used to describe this emerging transportation mode , including ride-sourcing , ride-hailing , TNC ’s , e-hailing , and app-based on-demand service .
#Text=Literature on the benefits and effectiveness of ride-hailing services is mixed .

#Text=Research points to several measurable advantages of the services , such as low waiting times and reduced commute-related stress , cost-effectiveness over other modes and congestion mitigation particularly for the shared-ride options .
#Text=On the other hand , the advanced technology of e-hailing does not guarantee success .
#Text=This is often due to key challenges , such as determining an appropriate local strategy for an e-hailing platform , and also frequent cancellations by passengers .
#Text=According to a study by Jin et al. , ride-hailing impacts the efficiency , equity , and sustainability of cities .
#Text=While ride-hailing offers economic efficiency in many cases , there have been issues reported related to discrimination and security among riders and drivers .
#Text=Also , the environmental impacts of ride-hailing remain to be substantively documented or tracked over time .
#Text=2.2.
#Text=The Comparison of Ride-hailing and Traditional Taxis
#Text=The literature points to several potential impacts of e-hailing on the traditional taxi industry .
#Text=Some studies have compared ride-hailing and yellow taxis side-by-side , and investigated the ways in which yellow taxis could compete with ride-hailing services .
#Text=A recent study in Shenzhen , China , found that taxis could effectively compete with ride-hailing services in peak periods and in dense areas .

#Text=It found that traditional taxis with experienced and professional drivers tended to operate more efficiently during peak hours and in more congested locations than the often-amateur drivers of ride-hailing services , many of whom rely heavily on GPS rather than personal knowledge .

#Text=This line of research posits that the emergence of ride-hailing is unlikely to eliminate the demand for traditional taxis , and both services are ultimately required ( and desired ) in large metropolitan areas .
#Text=Another line of research compares the influences of determinant factors on ride-hailing versus traditional taxi services .
#Text=Studies indicate that weather conditions may affect Uber and Lyft ridership more than yellow taxi ridership , likely due to their flexible pricing structure .
#Text=According to a study conducted in New York City , the number of Uber and Lyft rides per hour increases dramatically when it rains .
#Text=Evidence shows that ridership for yellow taxis is less likely to be influenced by rain .
#Text=Another study by Rayle et al. surveyed 380 ride-hailing patrons in San Francisco , and compared them with a control group of taxi riders in the same city .
#Text=Findings confirmed that frequent ride-hailing users were mostly younger , better educated , and more car-dependent than the control group of frequent taxi riders .
#Text=Moreover , time efficiency and convenience were found to be the main attractions for ride-hailing services .
#Text=Their average wait time was reported to be less than 10 minutes , and ride-hailing trips documented in the study were generally shorter than the control group ’s taxi trips .
#Text=Finally , a majority of the ride-hailing trips requested by patrons were for social purposes , indicating a robust pool of choice riders .
#Text=Other studies focused on determinants of traditional taxi demand .

#Text=For instance , Schaller , found that the number of employees using subway , households with no car ownership and the number of airport taxi trips accounted for the increasing number of taxi cabs in the US .
#Text=Another study , linked taxi demand with land use attributes , socio-demographics , and employment factors from 1972 ’s Traffic Analysis Zones ( TAZs ) in Washington DC .

#Text=Results confirm that land use measures such as residential density , employment density , average block size , and number of transit stations have a significant and positive impact on ridership demand for taxis .
#Text=At the same time , land use mix negatively correlates with the number of taxi pick-ups in each TAZ .
#Text=The study concludes by positing that the demand for taxis is higher in zones that host more workplaces than residences , such as central business districts ( CBD ’ s ) .
#Text=Among the sociodemographic factors , income was found to be positively related to taxi demand .
